CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, February 1, 1958, pg. 1, reads: "Baby Carried to Jail for Nursing - Five-month-old, 20-pound Joseph Boulding, who is suffering from a bad cold, has to be transported 40 miles a day (or a total of over 1,000 miles since Jan. 3) in order to be nursed four times daily by his mother, Dorothy Boulding, who is serving from six to 12 months in jail (along with $500 fine) on a lottery charge. The baby is carried each trip from Beaver Falls to the jail in Beaver by his great grandmother, Mrs. Gertrude Snowden.  The sentence, viewed as one of the stiffest numbers terms meted out in Beaver County's history, came after Judge Robert E. McCreary and District Attorney Richard S. Stewart did not believe that the baby's mother was telling the truth when she failed to give the complete identification of a racketeer. - Harris Photo."
TitMainTitle: Gertrude Snowden holding her great-grandson Joseph Boulding, and standing on sidewalk in front of Beaver County Jail, Beaver Falls
